newsitem.title: LUXEMBOURG: EU agrees airport ground-handling rules.
newsitem.headline: EU agrees airport ground-handling rules.

text.p: The European Union agreed on Tuesday to liberalise ground-handling services at airports in the 15-country bloc, confirming a decision transport ministers made last December.

"It's something the airlines have been pushing for a long, long time. While it's not ideal from their point of view, it does bring in some element of competition," a senior European Commission source said of the final decision.
The text was rubber-stamped, without discussion, at a meeting of the EU environment ministers in Luxembourg.
Plans to open up competition in airports' ground-handling services were thrown into doubt last July when a European parliamentary committee rejected a transport ministers' compromise.

But the position was overturned by a full session of the parliament, which rejected arguments by British Socialist member Barry Seal that liberalisation plans paid no heed to safeguarding jobs or standards.
"That was the decisive moment for the proposal," the official told Reuters.

The new rules will gradually liberalise airport services such as airport ramp services, baggage-handling, aircraft refuelling and passenger check-ins. Complete liberalisation of services is foreseen at the EU's main airports by 2003.
